title: Mrs Dalloway
description: The book by Virginia Woolf, Mrs Dalloway, explores the human experience in a captivating way, seamlessly weaving in her characters' inner lives through an unceasing stream of consciousness.

title: The Collected Dorothy Parker
description: "With a sharp-tongued and insightful perspective, Dorothy Parker scrutinizes the social norms of her time and uncovers hidden truths." -- Distributed by publisher.

title: Ulysses
description: Despite being written over a seven-year period, from 1914 to 1921, this book has managed to survive the bowdlerization, legal battles, and controversy. The novel portrays the events of one day in Dublin, now known as "Bloomsday" and includes Stephen Dedalus, Leopold Bloom, Molly (whose lives were tragically lost due to lack of translation), while Ulysses has been labeled dirty, blasphemous, or unreadable. Judge John M. Woolsey in 1933.

title: A Confederacy of Dunces
description: Ignatius Reilly, the hero of the story, is a sinister gargantua that rebels against the 20th century and its perverts and excesses. He travels through New Orleans to create chaos in his wake.

title: Speak  Memory
description: A book that chronicles Nabokov's life from his early days as a writer to his departure from Europe for America at the beginning of World War II, including his love for butterflies, passion for travel, and loss of his birthplace.

title: Howards End
description: The author's novel, inspired by Maurice and A Passage to India, explores personal connections and paradoxical perspectives. It has been filmed and directed by James Ivory and has featured performances from Anthony Hopkins, Vanessa Redgrave, Emma Thompson, Prunella Scales, James Wilby, Helena Bonham Carter, and Jemma Redford.

title: A Room of One's Own
description: The story was inspired by a speech given by Virginia Woolf at Girton College, Cambridge in 1928. It covers topics such as Jane Austen and Charlotte Bronte, the covert destiny of Shakespeare's fictional sister, and the influence of poverty and purity on female creativity.

title: Tender is the Night
description: In the post-C 1945 period, there are several genres of fiction: Modern & Contemporary Fiction, Classical Fantasy, and Contemporary Romance.

title: A Spy In The House Of Love
description: With a desire to only briefly encounter strangers, Sabina leads bourgeois and beautiful lives. She is driven by her own longing for sexual fulfillment and weaves ruffocious tales across New York. When the secrecy becomes too much for anyone to handle, she contacts an unknown man on his nightly phone and confesses guilt, which motivates him to seek her out.

title: Keep the Aspidistra Flying
description: Gordon Comstock, the copywriter of The Queen of Sheba Toilet Requisites in London in 1934, embarks on a new life as he begins selling poetry-writing books with disastrous results.

title: The Flame Trees of Thika
description: I srene och fyrheden p familiens kaffefarm om forfatterens undersom alla nybyggertilvrelse till du är det inte kommer att verdenskrig.

title: Orlando
description: In classic literature, Orlando embarks on a quest for passion, adventure, fulfillment, and youthfulness, abandoning his old age to explore the world. He travels from ancient England and Turkey to modern times. Will he be content with Sasha, the stunning novelist? Or will aspiring novelistic personality Shelmerdine bring her along? Is Orlando more interested in being pampered or treated like king/man?

title: The Good Soldier Svejk
description: The classic novel of the little man who defeats official and bureaucracy with only four weapons: passive resistance, subterfuge, native wit, and foolishness.

title: Rhinoceros
description: Three plays written by Ionesco, a founding father of absurd theatre, have been translated into English in this volume. They are considered to be lifeless and ideal for liberation.

title: Labyrinths
description: The Penguin Modern Classics edition of Jorge Luis Borges's Labyrinths features a collection of short stories and essays by the renowned author, Donald A. Yates and James E. Irby, along with an introduction by David L. Jordan and introductory commentary by André Maurois.

title: The Dharma Bums
description: Just one year after "On The Road" was published, this story follows two men who embark on a passionate quest for Dharma or truth. Their primary goal is to discover the Zen Way while ascending into the High Sierras to learn the lesson of solitude.

title: Tortilla Flat
description: Steinbeck drew inspiration from the Arthurian tale and constructed a "Camelot" on shabby hillside above Monterey on the California coast, complete with dozens of knights. He then recounts their thoughts, emotions, temptations, and desires in narrator-columns that are as gripping as the famous Round Table tales brought to life.

title: The Plague
description: A deadly plague has swept through the town of Oran, prompting the inhabitants to react in their own way: some blame themselves for the outbreak, others seek accountability, and some fight back with fear. This title is partly an allegory of France's horror during the Nazi occupation, but it also serves as a narrative of courage against the fragility of humanity that permeates modern society.

title: Orwell in Spain
description: The book Homage to Catalonia features Orwell's personal account of his experiences in the Spanish Civil War, as well as his written pieces, letters, and pamphlets, which demonstrate his resolve to reveal the truth about the war amidst widespread falsehoods from both the Communist Party and the British Press.

title: The Years
description: During the early 1900s, the Pargiter family's journey through the streets of London was documented as they struggled to establish their identity in a world filled with rapidly changing rules.

title: The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas
description: The Autogiography of Alice B. Toklas is a personal autobiography that portrays Gertrude Stein's life, with occasional glimpses of her early years in Paris until 1932.

title: Nausea
description: Antoine Roquentin, the introspective historian, recounts the disturbing changes in his perceptions and his quest to restore the meaning of life in an open and present-day context. This is Sartre's first published novel and also his first extended essay on existential philosophy.

title: The House of Bernarda Alba and Other Plays
description: Lorca, the Spanish theatre's revolutionary genius, brought life to the world with her powerful dramas that celebrate both tragedy and eroticism. They advocate for freedom, social justice, and passionate defense of the imagination.

title: Go Tell it on the Mountain
description: John is confronted with the issue of religious conversion in the Temple of the Fire Baptised, while the Grimes family experiences feelings of guilt and bitterness.

title: Answered Prayers
description: Answered Prayers, a highly malicious expose of the literary jet-set, was published in excerpts from Esquire magazine and caused outrage among Capote's social circle. The novel features P.B. Jones as the protagonist, who discovers that being bisexual is not only bad but also dangerous.

title: The Log from the Sea of Cortez
description: John Steinbeck's fishing trip with Ed Ricketts is the subject of this humorous journal. He combines science and adventure to explore his personal beliefs about human nature.

title: The Sea  the Sea
description: Charles Arrowby, after a successful career, enjoys his private sanctuary by the sea but soon discovers unrelenting past experiences.

title: A Fairly Honourable Defeat
description: The woman's wager of ten guinea with her ex-boyfriend could potentially cause harm to their loved ones.

title: Mysteries
description: A stranger's idiosyncratic behavior fills the air in a peaceful Norwegian town.

title: Giovanni's Room
description: This book, which was first published in 1957, seeks to resolve the tension between homosexual and heterosexual love. It tells the story of David, a young man who discovers his true homosexuality through his relationship with emancipated barman Giovanni, as he eagerly anticipates her arrival from Spain.

title: The Bell
description: The story follows the journey of a mixed group of lairs who live outside Imber Abbey, where an exclusive nunhood is established. Dora Greenfield, an unmarried wife, returns to her husband, and Michael Meade, who is confronted by his same-sex ex-lover.

title: The Call of Cthulhu and Other Weird Stories
description: H P Lovecraft, who is considered the father of horror in the twentieth century re-established the genre. In this book, S T Joshi presents selected works of his distinguished interpreter as Lovelaces' master's fiction, which illustrate how her narrative style evolved and establishes him as a canonical and visionary American writer.

title: Seven Gothic Tales
description: From Tuscany to Elisnore and Zanzibar, this collection of stories features a jealous countess who cannot bear her husband to admire her jewels, an Englishman embarking on an adventure, accompanied by aspiring women who believe they are famous for their romantic endeavors.

title: Orientalism
description: This edition by Penguin Modern Classics features Edward W. Said's Orientalism, which has been the basis for our understanding of colonialism and empire for generations. He wrote his preface shortly before his death in 2003. In this book, Edward SAID examines the history and nature of Western attitudes towards the East, viewing orientalism as an ideological creation that served as a tool for writers, philosophers, and colonists to combat the "otherness" of eastern culture, customs or beliefs.

title: Mr Majeika and the School Trip
description: Mr Majeika, the former witch who became a teacher, and his class at St Barty's School are back with more exciting adventures ahead. These trips take you on an amazing journey down mystical rivers, try to save their school from drowning, complete with work experience for Class Three.

title: The Duplicate
description: David, a sixteen-year-old boy, discovers an unusual device that generates replicas of living beings, but he recreates himself and experiences the severe aftermath when the duplicate becomes hostile.

title: The Beasties
description: Doug and his sister are about to encounter the Beasties, a group of creatures that are warring with humanity.

title: Crazy
description: On the first day of his new school, Benjamin Lebert, a 16-year-old cripple, presents himself as an outgoing student who engages in activities such as smoking, drinking, running away, meeting girls, and having sex.

title: Serena and the Sea Serpent
description: The Australian Bites series features a storyline that is tailored for primary school students, featuring spooky creatures and illustrations. Serena Smith is the only one who can stop the fierce sea serpent from causing harm to the residents of Blubber Point.

title: Skin and Other Stories
description: Introduces young adults to Roald Dahl's well-known adult short stories.

title: Westmark
description: Theo, a boy who is on the run from criminals, joins charlatans, dwarf attendants and urchin girls, travels with them through the kingdom of Westmark and finally makes it to the palace where the king mourns after losing his daughter. An ALA Notable Book. Reissue.

title: The Kestrel
description: Due to the war in Westmark and Mickle's accession, Theo requires all his abilities, as well as those of his former associates.

title: James and the Giant Peach
description: James's life is ruined by his aunts who constantly call him names, beat him on the cheek and starve him. He only became affected when he encountered a man who gave him crocodile tongues that would transform his parents' lives forever.

title: Boy
description: During my formative years in school and just afterwards, I remember many things that occurred to me that I have never forgotten. Roald Dahl's childhood experiences certainly provided inspiration for his novels, and his tales are not to be missed.

title: The Blue Sword
description: The Newbery Medal Honor Book, 1983, depicts Harry's experience of being kidnapped by a mysterious native king and finding magic in herself, after becoming disenchanted with her sheltered life in the far-off Daria settlement.

title: The Outsiders
description: To have a good time, the Socs fight against Greasers, including Ponyboy, who is known for his tough, long-haired nature and knows what to expect. He believes that he can count on his friends until someone takes it too far.

title: The Twits
description: The ugly face of a person is affected by their unappealing thoughts, which can become unbearable over time. How can you outsmart and humiliate the Twits?

title: Raffles  the Amateur Cracksman
description: The Ides of March/ A Costume Piece/ Gentlemen and Players/ Le Premier Pas/ Wilful Murder/ Nine Points of the Law/ The Return of a Gift of Mr Fraser. Raffles, the public-school gentleman, merges his passion for crime with his expertise in cricket. Here, we witness Rafels stealing from the nouveau riche and outwitting the law, thieving diamonds and bowling like he has poison, all with the assistance of his accomplice and ex-fag Bunny.

title: Frankenstein  Or  The Modern Prometheus
description: Written by Maurice Hindle.

title: Pygmalion
description: An unkempt London flower girl is transformed into a belle of the streets by Professor Higgins.

title: Emma
description: Edited editions featuring Tony Tanner's original introduction, further reading, and a new chronology were published.

title: A Tale of Two Cities
description: With an Introduction and Notes by Richard Maxwell.

title: The Woman in White
description: A commentary by Matthew Sweet, along with an Introduction and notes.

title: The Mill on the Floss
description: The latest chronology and additional reading, accompanied by an introduction by A. S. Byatt.

title: The Portrait of a Lady
description: Upon arrival in Europe from wealthy Aunt Touchett, an attractive and lively American woman, it is anticipated that she will marry shortly. However, Isabel has no reservations about rejecting two potential suitors due to her desire for freedom without fear of consequences. She ultimately realizes that wealth comes at the cost of independence.

title: Mansfield Park
description: Through the experiences of Fanny Price, the heroine, we are able to uncover the private and social lives of three families.

title: Robinson Crusoe
description: The BC DEFOE/ROBINSON CRUSOE.?

title: Vanity Fair
description: Written by John Carey.

title: The Turn of the Screw and The Aspern Papers
description: The plot of a literary historian involves the acquisition of romantic correspondences written by an American poet, while another woman's mother endeavors to shield her two young children from the paranormal.

title: Little Dorrit
description: Amy Dorrit, the daughter of a debtor in prison, is striving to free her family from the harsh realities of nineteenth-century English society while providing supplementary material, expanded notes, and informative information.

title: Tono-Bungay
description: The novel is a blend of social satire and science fiction, featuring George Ponderovo as the protagonist who leaves college to assist his uncle Edward in marketing 'a nice-tasting' fake medical cure-all called Tono-Bungay. Reprint.

title: A Passage to India
description: In Foster's most recent and finest novel, what transpired to Miss Quested in the Marabar Caves? This titillating interrogation provides an intriguing portrayal of race tension.

title: Moby-Dick  Or  The Whale
description: A chronicle of life aboard a whaling ship in New England during the 1800s, with the captain's obsession being the capture of jubilant white whales.

title: Icy Sparks
description: Having spent years in exile at a children's asylum due to her unpredictable behavior, Icy finally makes her way home and is soon befriended by Miss Emily, who takes the stress out of everyday life.

title: Bridget Jones's Guide to Life
description: The novel and the film, "Bridget Jones's Diary," features Bridget (the main character) Jones, who shares her own insights on cooking, home life, relationships, weight loss, self-improvement, and other topics.

title: Getting Things Done
description: Allen/doing everything correctly.

title: East of Eden
description: The Trask family's history in California, which spans two generations, is rooted in the biblical tale of Cain and Abel.

title: Cannery Row
description: Expressively portrays the colorful and occasionally disreputable inhabitants of a neglected neighborhood in Monterey, California.

title: Travels with Charley
description: In his native land, Steinbeck documents his feelings and encounters during a journey of rediscovery.

title: Salt
description: Examines the impact of salt on history, examining how the commodity has transformed economics, science, politics, religion, and culinary practices.

title: The Eyre Affair
description: Thursday Next, a Special Operative in the field of literary detection, endeavors to prevent the Third Most Wanted criminal from abducting Jane Eyre and other characters from literary works.

title: Youth
description: With the goal of fleeing his South African home, dysfunctional family, and an upcoming revolution, one young man becomes disillusioned with his monotonous life in London and embarks on a somber journey that mirrors the 1960s.

title: Word Freak
description: Initially, the book's protagonist was just a curious reporter who became engrossed in Scrabble and now enjoys playing the game. He then goes on to meet naughty standup comedians and play by Zen rules, ultimately understanding that SCRAbble is more than just fun.

title: The Fall of Berlin  1945
description: Describes the distressing events that occurred when Berlin was captured by the Soviets in 1945, including starvation, exposure, artillery fire, rape, and mass destruction as the Red Army finally took control of the city.

title: The Last American Man
description: A cultural survey of the modern American male delves into the paradoxical and problematic nature of manhood.

title: When the Elephants Dance
description: Three Filipino narrators depict the struggles of a group of people who were facing immense hardship during the Japanese occupation of the Philippines during World War II.

title: The Spy who Loved Me
description: While James Bond has met many women, Vivienne Michel stood out as an exception due to her unique qualities. Only one person can prevent her from becoming the ex-Ms Michel, who is now haunted by two male killers in the Canadian backwoods.

title: Octopussy
description: The legendary 007 confronts a wealthy, mentally unstable student who is unable to move on when his avaricious past becomes entangled in Octopussy and collaborates with naive russian agent during Southeby's bidding war for £250,000 in the second Bond adventure of The Living Daylights.

title: The Blank Slate
description: A leading authority on language and the mind scrutinizes the debate between nature and nurture to examine how humans reject basic human characteristics.

title: Good Poems
description: The radio program host presents some of his cherished poems, such as those by Emily Dickinson, Walt Whitman, Robert Frost, Charles Bukowski, Donald Hall, Billy Collins, Bob Bly, and Sharon Olds. Reissue.

title: The Classic Ten
description: Exposes the history, origins and historical value of the little black dress, white shirt, cashmere sweater, blue jeans, suit, high heel, pearls, lipstick, sneakers and trench coat.

title: I Should be Extremely Happy in Your Company
description: The fictionalized account of the Lewis and Clark expedition to the Pacific Ocean aims to portray the experiences of these pioneers and to bring the intermixing white and Native American cultures back into the forefront.

title: Drop City
description: The Drop City commune's members engage in a struggle with Alaskan homesteaders who live near the location of the commune, as they vie for love, food, and shelter.

title: River of Shadows
description: A historical account of Eadweardig's life that reflects nineteenth-century America includes his involvement in filmmaking technology and as a war photographer before being tried for the murder of his wife'S lover. Reprint. 25,000 first printing.

title: The Life of Graham Greene: 1904-1939
description: In the first volume of Norman Sherry's acclaimed biography, Graham Greene' life is described as complex and guarded, with letters, diaries, and interviews covering a range of events from teen suicide to courtship and marriage.

title: Voice of the Violin
description: Sicilian detective Salvo Montalbano uncovers suspects in the aging husband of one of the victims, a famous doctor who is missing along with an antiques dealer, friend of hers and 'a reclusive violinist' after discovering the murdered young woman's body. Reprint.

title: Zazie in the Metro
description: Despite being an impish and foul-mouthed girl, Zazie decides to travel to Paris with her imitator uncle Gabriel. However, she is shut down by a traffic accident and seeks alternative options before embarking on erroneous adventures.

title: Nuns and Soldiers
description: Count, a lonely Pole, Manfred North (a wealthy banker), and Tim Reade (an empty painter) are among the interesting characters whose lives intersect with those of Gertrude Openshaw and Anne Cavidge. Reprint.

title: A Year Down Yonder
description: In 1937, Mary Alice, a young girl who was sent to live with her gritty grandmother in rural Illinois during the economic downturn, finds that she has come to understand this woman of great courage.

title: Oliver and Albert  Friends Forever
description: Oliver and Albert, the youngest student in class, become friends and enjoy playing kickball and collecting bugs together. By Amanda Pig and Schoolgirl. Reprint.

title: The Philadelphia Adventure
description: The young lady is at home in Philadelphia during the last episode of the Vesper Holly adventures, where she can unwind until President Ulysses S. Grant requests her aid.

title: Dirty Beasts
description: The reissue features tales of an intelligent porcine who defeats a farmer, crocodile with children, hungry lion, scorpion in the face of death, aunt-eater ant, and flying cow.

title: A Robin McKinley Collection
description: Fans of Robin McKinley, the Newbery Award-winning author and fantasy fanatic, will appreciate a boxed set that features three of her most renowned books: Spindle's End, The Hero and the Crown, and The Blue Sword.

title: The Enormous Crocodile
description: The colossal reptile devises covert strategies and deceptive maneuvers to secure his meal, but his neighbors eventually kill it.

title: Triss
description: At Riftgard, Triss, Shogg, and Welfo abscond from slavery and are pursued by Princess Kurdah, Prince Bladd, along with a group of freebooters who search for the rumored treasure of Brockhall.

title: Pippi Longstocking
description: Annoyed by the behavior of a playful young lady who lives with swine and pigs, but is separated from her parents, in an isolated Swedish community. Reissue.

title: The Far Side of Evil
description: An advanced civilization sends a young girl as an observer to the planet where people have yet to control their use of atomic bombs.

title: Moon-Flash
description: Kyreol and Terje travel beyond their imaginary home of Riverworld to discover new planets and ways of life, having dreamt that they must leave their isolated home. Reissue.

title: Firebirds
description: Featuring the works of several award-winning authors, including Diana Wynne Jones, Garth Nix, Lloyd Alexander, Nancy Farmer, and Meredith Ann Pierce, sixteen original stories are published as an ALA Best Book for Young Adults. Reprint.

title: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory
description: Each of the five children who are lucky enough to find an entry ticket into Mr. Willy Wonka's enigmatic chocolate factory takes advantage of this in his own way.

title: Rock Star Superstar
description: Despite his love for music, Pete must eventually sign up with a popular yet uninspired band that is on the verge of becoming renowned. This book is an ALA Best Book for Young Adults & Quick Pick and has been redacted.

title: Amber Brown Is Not a Crayon
description: Amber's third-grade experience is disheartening because her best friend Justin is getting ready to move to a far-off state.

title: The Tough Guide to Fantasyland
description: In this one-of-a-kind guide to fantasy literature, readers can learn about everything from virginity to the evil nature of High Priests, the existence of minions as Dark Lords and the wise ways to deal with being captured by a Goblin. Reprint.

title: Heat
description: Michael Arroyo, a gifted pitcher, is on the run from social services after being prohibited from playing Little League baseball because of doubts from opposing coaches and lack of parental evidence.

title: The BFG
description: With minimal experience or resources, a set of plays from the author's book can be staged, with notes on staging, props, and costumes included. Reprint.

title: I'm Afraid You've Got Dragons
description: Robert has recently been appointed as the new dragon catcher/exterminator, but his current job poses challenges for him as he is fond of the creatures that inhabit Bellemontagne and has always harbored dreams of being a prince's servant, which transcends his humble beginnings.

title: A Little Princess
description: Sara Crewe, a student at Miss Minchin's London school, is left in debt after her father passes away, but she is rescued by an unknown benefactor.

title: The Letters of John and Abigail Adams
description: John and Abigail Adams' letters from more than fifty years ago offer a unique perspective on their significant family members in America before, during, and after the Revolution.

title: Jane Eyre
description: Reveals the age-old orphanage story of a young woman who accepts governmental positions and eventually falls in love with her employer.

title: On the Road
description: Tracks the escapades of Beat generation members who travel from coast to coast in search of meaning and pleasure.

title: The Portable Faulkner
description: Collects stories from Faulkner that illustrate his reconstructed history of the southern United States, located in Yoknapatawpha County, Mississippi.

title: The Power and the Glory
description: An idealistic Mexican lieutenant pursues a tormented, alcoholic priest during an anti-clerical persecution.

title: The Portable Dante
description: Encompasses "The Divine Comedy," " The New Life," and other handcrafted poems, prose, and letters, as well as biographical and introductory notes.

title: The Portable Arthur Miller
description: This compilation features 60 years of writing from the most renowned American playwright, including "The Crucible" and "Death of a Salesman."

title: Agapē Agape
description: A man on the brink of death lies in bed, contemplating how to write a book and complaining about the impending decline of civilization in the final novel of A Frolic of His Own.

title: In the Land of Time  and Other Fantasy Tales
authors: Edward John Moreton Drax Plunkett Baron Dunsany
description: Lord Dunsany is considered a pioneer of imaginative literature and has gained esteem for his impact on modern fantasy literature, including works by J.R.L. Tolkien and H. P. Lovecraft. This one-of-a-kind collection of short stories spans over five decades. It includes liberal selections of earlier tales such as "Idle Days of the Yann" and "The Fortress Unvanquishable, Save for Sacnoth," followed by memorable later installments.

title: The Portable John Adams
description: This collection of writings by America's second president includes selections from his letters to Abigail, diary excerpts, parts of his memoirs and such political works as: a "Discussion on Canon and Feudal Law," "Thoughts on Government", "A Defense of Constitutions," an epigraph on Novanglus" and the poem "Discourse on Davila." Original.

title: Aleph and other stories
description: The twentieth book in the series provides a glimpse into the lives of an unapologetic Nazi, imprisoned Mayan priests, devout Christian theologians, grumpy Christian preachers, one man on the brink of murdering his assassin, and pious woman seeking revenge on her father's "killer."

title: A Universal History of Iniquity
description: In his writing, Borges consistently merged seriousness and a wicked sense of amusement. He relishes the opportunity to recreate rich tales from various cultures, including the Orient, Islam, or the Wild West; also, he is fascinated by the prevalence of knife fights, political and personal betrayal, and revenge. This book epitomizes an entirely different literary sensibility that blossomed with the exuberant pleasure of storytelling.

title: Stamboul Train
description: Demonstrates the peculiar relationship between a man and sex while on the Orient Express.

title: Enchantress from the Stars
description: Young Elana joins the team on a mission to explore Andrecia, becoming an essential member of three civilizations that are situated on the third planet in its own solar system. A Newbery Honor book from 1971 is reproduced.

title: Castaways of the Flying Dutchman
description: The Flying Dutchman shipwreck in 1620 involves an angel rescuing a boy and his dog, who are guided by the spirit to aid those in need throughout their journey.

title: Salamandastron
description: The wise old badger Urthstripe the Strong leads the animals of the great fortress of Salamandastron and Redwall Abbey against the weasel Ferahgo the Assassin and his corpse of vermin.

title: Riot
description: Who was responsible for the death of Priscilla Hart, a twenty-year old American student who had been volunteering in prestigious women's health programs in India?

title: Buddha
description: The Buddha's life story recounts his journey from being a religious icon to reaching spiritual maturity, all while maintaining his archetypal qualities.

title: Excursion to Tindari
description: Inspector Salvo Montalbano of Sicily investigates two unrelated killings--the murder of a young Casanova and the mysterious disappearance of an elderly couple during their visit to Tindari.

title: Alexander Hamilton
description: The House of Morgan, a definitive biography by the National Book Award-winning author, recounts the personal life of Alexander Hamilton, an orphan born in the Caribbean who later became George Washington's assistant and eventually became the first Treasury Secretary of the United States.

title: The Shadow of the Wind
description: A boy's journey through the midst of post-World War II Barcelona to find an unknown author, whose book has been as perilous as it is unforgettable, has made The Runaway from Spain a runaway success in the Spanish market.

title: Jane Austen
description: A critical biography of Jane Austen, the author of The Stone Diaries who won the Pulitzer Prize, focuses on her life and work in both fiction and life.

title: The Liars' Club
description: A poet's account of her troubled upbringing in a Texas oil town is shared by the author.

title: Democracy Matters
description: Examines the dangers to democracy in the United States and in parts like the Middle East, focusing on the corruption that corrupts our own democracy, the failure to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and other issues.

title: Windblown World
description: The personal diaries of the renowned Beat author contain fragments and passages that trace a crucial phase in Kerouac's life, including his debut novel, The Town and City, his close relationships with Allen Ginsberg, William S. Burroughs, and Neal Cassady, as well as his own interpretation of events from On the Road. Reprint.

title: The United States of Europe
description: The European Union, now made up of 25 countries and 450 million citizens, has a larger number of people, wealth, and votes than the United States. The author discusses the threat to American political and economic dominance.

title: The Christians and the Fall of Rome
description: Penguin's Great Ideas series features twelve works by the most significant thinkers, pioneers, radicals and visionaries who revolutionized society and helped shape our future. Each volume is beautifully packaged with a unique type-drive design that highlights the work of the bookmaker. This collection is perfect for those seeking great literature in great quantities at great prices.

title: Why I Write
description: In the Great Ideas series, Penguin presents a selection of books that have left an indelible impact on society and beyond, including those written by some of the most influential thinkers, pioneers or visionaries.

title: The Stone Diaries
description: Carol Shields' The Stone Diaries transformed our understanding of storytelling by transforming it into a Pulitzer Prize-winning book. The novel, disguised as narrator's autobiography and written in lyrical language, gradually becomes infused with seductive truths and an examination of the dichotomy between fact, fiction, and the ambiguous, undefined expanse of space.

title: Collapse
description: Penguin Group, USA has discontinued the sale of this title.

title: March
description: A story based on the father character in Little Women, with commentary from Bronson's journals and letters, follows a man who deserts his family to fight in the Civil War, leaving his marriage and beliefs profoundly affected by his experiences.

title: The Mermaid Chair
description: Upon arriving at Egret Island, Jessie Sullivan meets Brother Thomas, a monk who is about to take his last vows, and shares the story of ecclesiastical chair on which he had been raised from when saint Amadeus was originally born.

title: Grammar Snobs are Great Big Meanies
description: The humorous compilation of witty anecdotes and insightful essays on the perplexing topics of grammar and punctuation takes aim at self-appointed language experts as it tackles subjects such as predicate nominatives, colons/silentines, quotation marks, prepositions (including plurals), hyphens or other words. Original.

title: The City of Falling Angels
description: The author researched the aftermath of the 1996 Venice opera house fire, which caused significant damage to Venetian society and exposed the cultural legacy of their region through interviews with locals.

title: Bargaining for Advantage
description: Revised edition with a first printing featuring 15,000 pages.

title: The Memory Keeper's Daughter
description: A first novel featuring a doctor who delivers his twin babies in squalor and secretly raises the child for his wife with Down Syndrome. The story spans two decades and is included in the first edition of 100,000 copies.

title: The Big Over Easy
description: A conspiracy involving money laundering and asylum-seeking titans is exposed by detective inspector Jack Spratt and his assistant, Mary Mary, who are not convinced that the ex-wife of a former convict turned millionaire philanthropist has been murdered by her husband.

title: The Read-aloud Handbook
description: Elucidates the significance of reading to children, provides tips on creating a read-aloud environment in the home or classroom, and suggests appropriate titles to choose from.

title: Tooth and Claw
description: The book is comprised of fourteen tales, such as "The Kind Assassin," where a radio shock jock sets euphoric heights in the early days of television; "Dogology," which tells an obsessed woman who completely forgets her own identity; and the title story, in which he bet against vengeful African cats.

title: Rounding the Mark
description: Two seemingly inextricably linked homicides thrust Inspector Montalbano into a dangerous web of unlawful human trafficking, which tests his loyalty to the institution he is assigned to.

title: The Social Contract
description: The Social Contract and The First Discourse, as well as The Second Discharge (Discourse on the Origin and Foundations of Inequality) and "The Social Contradiction" are three of Rousseau's most important political works, with essays by leading scholars contributing to these texts.

title: Fear and Trembling
description: With its stunning packaging, the Great Ideas series from Penguin is a must-read for true bookworms. It includes twelve groundbreaking works by prominent thinkers, all of which are beautifully illustrated with their own unique designs.

title: Bleak House
description: Dickins' account of the case of Jarndyce vs. Jarnduzzie parodies the English equity court of that century.

title: Good Poems for Hard Times
description: Provides a compilation of motivational verses by Emily Dickinson, Billy Collins, Robert Frost, and Raymond Carver.

title: Homegrown Democrat
description: The comedian and radio personality delves into the "politics of kindness" by sharing a collection of nostalgic reflections, contemplations, and observations on the essential qualities of democracy.

title: Let My People Go Surfing
description: His book chronicles his difficult childhood in southern California as an immigrant, his early success as a mountain climber, and the company's commitment to quality and environmental consciousness. Reprint. 75,000 first printing.

title: The Joy Luck Club
description: The tale of four resilient women, spanning two generations and a rich source of Chinese and American history, also uncovers their daughter's past through memories and emotions.

title: The Kitchen God's Wife
description: An elderly Chinese woman named Winnie Louie, who is certain that she will pass away soon, decides to release the secrets of her family and a questionable Americanized daughter.

title: The Bar on the Seine
description: Upon visiting a prisoner to verify that his escape has been denied and that the execution is imminent, Inspector Maigret listens to their story and conducts specialized investigations that lead him to the Guinguette à Deux Sous, surrounded by the Seine. Reprint.

title: Eat  Pray  Love
description: GILBERT/EAT PRAY LOVE.

title: The White Man's Burden
description: According to the author of The Elusive Quest for Growth, western foreign aid efforts have failed in curbing global poverty. They point out that the International Monetary Fund and World Bank are not held responsible for ineffective practices that enter into the inner workings of other countries.

title: The quiet American
description: "The centennial of Graham Greene's existence, from 1904 to 2004"--Cover.

title: Complete Short Stories
description: The Quiet American and The Third Man author's definitive collection of short stories features forty-nine stories that explore various aspects of human life, including works that were originally published in two volumes, namely Collected Short Stories andThe Last Word and Other Stories.

title: World of Wonders
description: Magnus Eisengrim, the celebrated magician who stars in a movie being shot in Switzerland, spends his spare time recounting his tragic life to his producer and director, aide, cameraman, mysterious hostess, and Canadian schoolmaster in the third volume of the Deptford Trilogy. Reprint.

title: Sodom and Gomorrah
description: Against the backdrop of an impoverished high society in Paris, with its conservative upper class gradually replacing it, the author explores the theme of gay love and the destructive consequences of sexual jealousy.

title: The Grapes of Wrath
description: STEINBECK/GRAPS OF WRATH (BC)

title: The Tale of Genji
description: Modern readers are introduced to the Japanese masterpiece's exceptional depiction of court life in medieval Japan, which is translated into English for the first time in a generation and includes line drawings, notes, glossaries, maps, character lists, and chronologies.

title: The Complete Novels
description: The author's seven great novels are combined to create a detailed and vivid portrayal of English middle-class life, institutions, and society during the late 1800s.

title: The Adventures of Augie March
description: Augie's nonconformity results in him leading an eventful, humorous, and occasionally earthy existence.

title: Malgudi Days
description: In his collection of stories, R. K. Narayan highlights the skillful storytelling of Indian writers such as Malgudi Days, which showcases a variety of characters including astrologists, snake charmers, postmen, and sweethearts.

title: Sometimes a Great Notion
description: The extraordinary second novel by the renowned author of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is set in an otherwise fantastic setting.

title: The Book of Imaginary Beings
authors: Jorge Luis Borges;Margarita Guerrero;Andrew Hurley;Peter Sís
description: A humorously satirical book that analyzes the works of literary greats such as Shakespeare, Lewis Carroll, and Kafka offers a selection of mythological creatures' characteristics.

title: Gravity's Rainbow
description: In 1944, Tyrone Slothrop, a GI stationed in London, is under suspicion by his superiors and soon discovers that he is on the run through Germany.

title: Life is a Dream
description: This 17th-century allegory is one of the most remarkable Spanish dramas of all time and explores the enigma of human destiny, the delusional nature of existence, and the struggle between predestination and free will.

title: Black Lamb and Grey Falcon
description: West's travel journal, cultural commentary, and historical insight into Yugoslavia are all beautifully combined, making it a classic work of art and history written on the eve of World War II.

title: Mrs. Dalloway
description: An emotional account of the events and thoughts that take place on a typical woman's first day.

title: Animal Farm and 1984
description: Alongside "1984," George Orwell's classic satire on totalitarianism depicts life in a future time where no government is responsible for the actions of farm animals that overthrow their human owner.

title: Janet Flanner's world
description: The collection features an early profile of Hitler, reports on the Nuremberg trials, portraits of Thomas Mann, Bette Davis, Picasso, and concerts and art exhibits. Edited by Irving Drutman and prefaced with a commentary by William Shawn.

title: The Stone Fey
description: A fey and Maddy, a young woman who manages sheep on her family farm, have an unlikely bond due to their encounter.

title: How I Became a Pirate
description: Jeremy Jacob is introduced to Braid Beard and his pirate team, uncovering the language, manners, and other essentials of pirate culture.

title: The Little Red Lighthouse and the Great Gray Bridge
description: A tale that was first published in 1942 depicts a small lighthouse on the Hudson River who takes pride in its continued usefulness and important role.

title: The Secret School
description: In 1925, the one-room schoolhouse in her distant Colorado neighborhood abruptly shuts down, and Ida Bidson, a fourteen-year-old girl, takes on the role of teacher.

title: Winter is the Warmest Season
description: A young girl explains how she can enjoy warm temperatures in the winter by drinking hot chocolate and eating grilled cheese sandwiches, as well as wearing woolly sweaters and sitting near a glowing fireplace.

title: Doomed Queen Anne
description: In 1520, Anne Boleyn, a thirteen-year-old girl, declares that she will one day be queen of England and that her older sister will kneel at her feet due to jealousy of her beauty and position in court.

title: Gifts
description: By choosing to blind himself instead of using his own violent talent, "unmaking," a young man in the Uplands disrupts the delicate balance of power among rival families with their unique and deadly talents.

title: The Hundred Dresses
description: A small Polish girl, who is not in the running to win a medal, instructs her classmates on how to do things right. The note is signed by Helena Estes, the daughter of the author.

title: Patience  Princess Catherine
description: Upon her arrival in England in 1501, Catharine of Aragon, aged fifteen, marries Arthur, the eldest son of King Henry VII, but her sudden and untimely death sparks a bitter conflict between England and Spain over her future.

title: Voices
description: Young Memer becomes a key player in liberating her war-torn country from its oppressive captors.

title: Apple Pie Fourth of July
description: A Chinese American child is worried that the food her parents are selling on the Fourth of July will not be consumed.

title: Beauty Shop for Rent
description: Abbey, who was raised by a great-grandmother and beauty shop friends, is determined to overcome her unhappy childhood and disillusionment with her mother who abandoned her.

title: Frankenstein Makes a Sandwich
description: VIDEO: Monster-sized problems — monsters like Dracula, Wolfman, and Bigfoot.

title: The Sleeping Giant and Other Stories
description: Eleanor Estes has written and illustrated three short tales: The sleeping monster -- The shadow that disappears -- A place where giraffes can be found.

title: The Metamorphoses of Ovid
description: A new translation of the most famous Roman poet's witty and irreverent work captures the mischievous spirit of a man of letters who wrote candid poems about love and his own death in exile.

title: Winterdance
description: Paulsen and his canines fought through snowstorms, frostbite, dogfights in the name of defense, moose attacks, sleeplessness, and hallucinations as they endeavored to continue. Map and color photographs.

title: This Is the Way the World Ends
description: George Paxton was a typical person until the nuclear holocaust, and now he's about to uncover what happens after the end of the world. "Astute, captivating, yet ultimately moving", states the Los Angeles Times.

title: The Double Flame
description: The subjects of love and sex in literature from Plato to modern times are the focus of this collection of essays.

title: All the King's Men
description: Willie Stark's preoccupation with power results in the ultimate corruption of his gubernatorial government.

title: Baltasar and Blimunda
description: During the 18th century in Portugal, while fifty thousand laborers are carrying stones on their backs to construct the king's convent, a heretical priest creates enigmatic flying machines called the Passarola, and two lovers' dreams of taking flight separate them.

title: The History of the Siege of Lisbon
description: Raimundo Silva's actions change a key word in he history text, leading him to romance and changing the course of European history while living the innocent life of blond proofreaders.

title: Slammerkin
description: In mid-1700s London, Mary Saunders was drawn to prostitution at a young age because of her aspirations of achieving opulent status. She finds solace in the middle-class household of Mrs. Jones and believes that fashionable clothing can lead to self-rule and respect.

title: Blindness
description: The city suffers from "white blindness," which causes its residents to be confined to an abandoned mental institution, while a sole witness navigates seven peculiar strangers through the deserted urban landscape.

title: All the Names
description: A drone found in the Central Registry catches a stray unfiled birth certificate, prompting him to investigate and lead him towards the woman he believes is the right person.

title: Poems  New and Collected  1957-1997
description: Contains one hundred poems, with the author's "View with a Grain of Sand" and sixty-four newly-translated selections included.

title: The Last Life
description: Set in the middle of North Africa, France, and New England, the LaBasse family's secrets are revealed to the public.

title: The Tale of the Unknown Island
description: The Nobel Prize for Literature winner's story of a man who petitions the king for enfeoff, volunteers his services, and sets sail in reprint. First printing: 25,000 copies.

title: Tales from Margaritaville
description: A collection of witty, down-to-earth Southern tales and insightful essays showcases the singer/songwriter's talent for storytelling.

title: The Cyberiad
description: Trurl and Klaupacius are robots that can create new things on their own. They travel to remote locations to take on freelance problems, but their actions could be detrimental to their employers.

title: Four Comedies
description: The latest English renditions of Lysistrata, The Frogs, the Birds and Ladies' Day. Thanks to Dudley Fitts we can now appreciate Aristophanes' vigor, his sharp style, fiery humor, dedication to truth, and even his poetic imagination."

title: The Common Reader
description: The debut and most renowned collection of essays by Woolf. It features over twenty-five options, including significant statements like "Modern Fiction" and "The Modern Essay." Edited and updated with an Introduction by Andrew McNeillie; Index.

title: A Writer's Diary
description: The personal file that Virginia Woolf kept for twenty-seven years has been utilized by her husband to extract information about the author's art and mind.

title: Women and Writing
description: Her novels and doyenne of the 'Bloomsbury Set' earned her significant respect as an essayist and critic during her time, with a particular emphasis on contemporary literature and women's writing. This impressive compilation of essays and other writings is devoted to these endeavors and provides exceptional insights into the lives of Aphra Behn, Mary Wollstonecraft, the Duchess of Newcastle, Dorothy Richardson, Charlotte Bronte, and Katherine Mansfield, among others.

title: The Cave
description: Upon learning that his clay pots and jugs are no longer required, Cipriano, an elderly potter, turns his attention to ceramic doll-making, but the unexpected revelation undermines his family's accomplishments.

title: Gun  with Occasional Music
description: In a strange, noir-themed world shared by humans and intelligent beings, Conrad Metcalf, ten years his private detective, discovers that one of his cases has drawn him into gangsters and the Inquisitor's office.

title: A Drink Before the War
description: Private detective partners Patrick Kenzie and Angela Gennaro are tasked with finding Jenna Angeline, a missing black cleaning woman who is accused of stealing confidential state documents. However, their investigation becomes complicated by rival gang leaders, child prostitution, assassination reaching the highest levels of government, leading to the realization that their target has been framed. Reprint. 15,000 first printing.

title: Baudolino
description: Baudolino's upbringing in northern Italy as a simple-minded peasant is the basis of his life, which includes being adopted by Emperor Frederick Barbarossa and educated in Paris before finally arriving in Constantinople during the Fourth Crusaded.

title: Mrs. Dalloway's Party
description: Virginia Woolf's ideas about the party organized by Mrs. Dalloway are expanded or continued in seven short stories in her famous 1925 novel Mrs.

title: The Liberated Bride
description: Haifa University professor Yohanan Rivlin becomes fixated on the failed marriage of his son and begins researching turbulent recent Algerian history with help from a young Arab bride from nearby Galilee village. Reprint. 35,000 first printing.

title: The Female of the Species
description: Short works include "So Help Me God," in which the young wife is asked by a mob about who called her home, and "Madison at Guignol," where an unhappy fashionista discovers something horrible at some clothing store.

title: Flowers for Algernon
description: The classic story of a mentally challenged man, whose scientific pursuit for intelligence is similar to that of Algernon, an extraordinary laboratory mouse, has sold over five million copies.

title: To the Lighthouse
description: After a 10-year hiatus, an English family's intricate lives are revisited to investigate the effects of time.

title: Kiffe Kiffe Tomorrow
description: A first novel in which a fifteen-year-old French Muslim struggles with an overworked mother, an absent father, and the hardships of living in the infamous Paradise projects of suburban Paris while facing plight (her mother was too hard on her to do anything meaningful for someone else) Doria is forced to endure 'first kisses' and adopt opportunistic beliefs about her circumstances. Original print price: 75,000.

title: Rose of No Man's Land
description: The story of Trisha Driscoll, a fourteen-year-old girl who is fired from the most popular shop in Square One Mall in Mogsfield, Massachusetts, follows two eccentric girls who explore the hollowness of modern culture.

title: Three Guineas
description: An engrossed English writer pleads passionately for intellectual freedom, women's rights, and the cessation of warfare, in annotated letter format. Reprint. 12,000 pages.

title: The People of Paper
description: After his wife is left to abandon him, Federico de la Fe and his daughter escape to California, where they encounter a strange woman, meet another man who is heartbroken, and move on. A first novel. Reprint.

title: Virginia Woolf
description: Reprint: A portrait of the influential twentieth-century writer breaks away from traditional examinations of her Bloomsbury social circles and reveals how her life revolved around her writing (drawn from letters, diaries and essays) to explain how those works reflect her formative years and creative philosophies.

title: On Literature
description: The author's collection of essays and addresses includes his reflections on Ptolemy, experimental writings by Borges and Joyce, and confessions about his own ambitions and anxieties. Reprinted with permission.

title: The Pirates Laffite
description: Privateers Jean and Pierre Laffite caused havoc among Spanish merchants on the Gulf after the Louisiana Purchase until the War of 1812, with pirates being responsible for their pursuit and New Orleanians shoppers seeking contrabans.

title: Foucault's Pendulum
description: An extraordinary myth about a mystic source of power greater than atomic energy prompts three editors to feed unknown bits of knowledge into an advanced computer, leading to the creation of an amazing game that takes over. Reprint.

title: Between the Acts
description: Following a day of pageantry and emotional turmoil, Isa and her husband must confront each other.

title: Big Anthony and the Magic Ring
description: Big Anthony encounters more difficulties than pleasure when he takes advantage of Strega Nona's magic ring to appear attractive.

title: The Collected Stories of Eudora Welty
description: The story collection, which includes her most famous piece, "Death of a Traveling Salesman," showcases the forty-one stories that she has written and brought to life.

title: The Complete Shorter Fiction of Virginia Woolf
description: Hear him recounting the chronologically and almost fifty short stories and sketches he wrote throughout Woolf's writing career, in order to provide insight into his development as a writer.

title: The Diary of Anaïs Nin: 1939-1944
description: The debate on drug use and artist imagination persists, with Nin portraying various prominent figures in art history and examining her travels to Sweden (France), the Brussels World's Fair Paris, and Venice. She writes about a warm and compassionate humanity that is not often found in contemporary literature."

title: The Diary of Anaïs Nin
description: The debate on drug use and artist imagination persists, with Nin portraying various prominent figures in art history and examining her travels to Sweden (France), the Brussels World's Fair Paris, and Venice. She writes about a warm and compassionate humanity that is not often found in contemporary literature."

title: The Diary of Virginia Woolf: 1915-1919
description: The New York Times notes that the publication of this book is unprecedented, as it provides an opportunity to meet Virginia Woolf in person without the need for a commentary.

title: The Diary of Virginia Woolf
description: Virginia Woolf's life and her responses to people, books, and personal work are documented in periodic breakdowns that only serve as a reminder of her daily activities.

title: The Diary of Virginia Woolf: 1925-1930
description: The life of Woolf during the time of To the Lighthouse and The Waves is narrated in elegant prose, with a steel trap mentality that will make this book highly valuable.

title: The Diary of Virginia Woolf: 1931-1935
description: Virginia Woolf's life and her responses to people, books, and personal work are documented in periodic breakdowns that only serve as a reminder of her daily activities.

title: Diary Of Virginia Woolf Volume 5
description: The last page of Virginia Woolf's diary, which was written four days before she drowned on March 28, 1941, was published in the final volume. She turned fifty-four on January 25, 1936, three weeks after the first publication of this book.

title: Difficult Loves
description: The author's collection of 1940s and 1950s stories depicts moments of insight in the lives of common people, blending recognition with fear as deceptions were exposed.

title: The Early Diary of Anaïs Nin: 1923-1927
description: Nin's Diary, the first volume, offers a glimpse into her early life and is more candid than her previous diaries. It includes an epilogue from her exorcist who exposed herself to the obsession that endangered her marriage and nearly caused her suicide.

title: E. M. Forster
description: The 1978 two-volume portrait by P. N. Furbank, published as a single edition, is widely recognized as the ultimate biography of novelist E. M. Forster and is considered one of the best biographies of any writer.

title: Fiasco
description: Upon reaching the planet Quinta, an expedition of earthmen led by a space pilot, military leader, scientist, and priest exposes the travelers to the very depths of human existence.

title: Henry and June
description: Anais Nin, the writer, met Henry Miller and his wife June during their ensuing year (1931-1932).

title: Homage to Catalonia
description: Contains the firsthand account of the British author's experiences during the Spanish Civil War, including his battles against the Fascists.

title: Incest
description: Her diary entries reveal her relationships with Henry Miller and his wife, June, Antonin Artaud, Rene Allendy, Otto Rank, and her father.

title: The Inheritors
description: A small group of Neanderthal food gatherers are impacted by the arrival of Homo sapiens, an intelligent and merciless predator.

title: Invisible Cities
description: The young Marco Polo, seated in Kublai Khan's garden at sunset, diverts the old emperor from his preoccupation with the imminent collapse of his empire by recounting tales of numerous cities, past, present, and future.

title: The Letters of Virginia Woolf: 1936-1941
description: The uncut versions of almost all of the present-day correspondence between the English novelist and her family, documenting her personality, activities, relationships, spells of madness, and development as a writer from when she was six to shortly before her death.

title: Marcovaldo  Or  The Seasons in the City
description: Marcovaldo, an inexplicable dreamer and ruthless hacker, embarks on a series of adventures that have unpredictable outcomes.

title: Moments of Being
description: Woolf's career is reflected in six autobiographical works, which demonstrate the interplay between art, philosophy, and sensibility, as well as her remarkable ability to incorporate personal experiences into her fiction.

title: Mrs. Miniver
description: Mrs. Miniver, a mother of three and an English wife who grew up in prewar England, finds remarkable things about her everyday life that others take for granted.

title: Murder in the Cathedral
description: The murder of Archbishop Thomas Becket by four knights of Henry II's court is the subject of a verse-based play.

title: The Nonexistent Knight & The Cloven Viscount
description: narrates the heroic adventures of an uncut suit of armor and the two halves of a hereditary who has been split into two by armed cannon fire.

title: The Orwell Reader
description: The evolution of Orwell's personality and thinking in the thirties and forties is evident in Selections.

title: The Philosophy of Andy Warhol
description: In his observations on love, beauty, fame, work, and art, Warhol reveals the continuous play and display of his various fetishes.

title: Travels in Hyper Reality
description: The Middle Ages, language, culture, media, sports, fashion, photography, films, and philosophy are all topics covered in these essays.

title: The Uses of Literature
description: The essay collection explores literature in relation to science, philosophy, and politics in studies of renowned classical works and tributes paid to contemporary authors such as Eugenio Montale, Roland Barthes, or Marianne Moore.

title: The Virginia Woolf Reader
description: Features five short stories, essays, letters, and selections from four novels written by the renowned British author.

title: The Waste Land
description: Biographical material is included alongside reproductions of T. S. Eliot's original manuscript and notes.

title: The Watcher & Other Stories
description: Grotesque or farcical events of the future are the subject of an Italian writer's attention.

title: The Waves
description: The author depicts a group of characters from the early 1900s who talk in soliloquy against the sea, with one character ultimately emphasizing the overall impact of their lives.

title: Tales of the Norse Gods
description: Contains tales of heroic women, warrior boots, courage in battle, mythical figures, monsters, wizards and wizardry, as well as Viking gods who were influenced by Norse folklore.

title: Party Shoes
description: Selina is sent a package from America with opulent party dress and shoes, but her joy wanes as she waits for the chance to wear them. It's not until she and her cousins organize pinning pageants that everyone takes part in an official celebration, which was supposed to honor World War II on November 26.

title: Cart And Cwidder
description: As they work as musicians on the move, Clennen and his family earn a livelihood. However, danger mounts high above them, leading to Moril being given possession of the mysterious cwidder.

title: Moby Dick  Or  The White Whale
description: Relives from Melville's novel that portrays Ishmael and Captain Ahab as sailors who would go to great lengths to catch the mobo, which had taken his leg.

title: Typhoon and Other Tales
description: In this book, there are four autobiographical stories. The first one relates Conrad's experience at sea and his exile from his homeland of Poland.

title: Hegel: A Very Short Introduction
description: Despite the fact that Hegel's work is often considered obscure and challenging, his significance and impact are widely recognized. Peter Singer challenges the notion of being uninformed by Hegelian thought by providing a comprehensive examination of his concepts and an index to his significant works (including several seminal works).

title: Persuasion
description: The relationship between Captain Wentworth and Anne, the daughter of Sir Walter Elliot, appears to be ruined by the young man's family connections and lack of financial resources.

title: Egyptian Myth: A Very Short Introduction
description: Egyptian myths embodied the fundamental principles of one of the most enduring societies in history, while deities like Isis and Osiris influenced modern cultures and were integrated into Western culture. Egyptian Mythology: A Very Short Introduction provides a comprehensive introduction to the rich and varied world of Egyptian mythography, with chapters dedicated to objects such as Cleopatra's Needle.

title: The Major Works
description: This authoritative edition, which was originally published in the Oxford Authors series under the general editorship of Frank Kermode, combines Milton's poetry and prose with a generous selection from the major proson texts to capture the essence of his ideas.

title: Gulliver's Travels
description: "Gulliver's travels is billed as a work of fantasy and realism, chronicling Gulliver'Standard adventure with the people of four places: Lilluput, Brobdingnag, Laputa and the Houyhnhms"--Published by Gillian Anderson.

title: A Christmas Carol and Other Christmas Books
description: Stoods up some of the author's Christmas stories, including "A Christmas Carol," in which a miser discovers the true meaning of Christmas when three ghostly visitors examine his past and predict his future.

title: Candide and Other Stories
description: Voltaire's most famous "philosophical tale" is Candide, which combined witty improvisations with the most sensible ones. This edition features four other prose stories (Micromegas, Zadig, The Ing--ecirc-;nu, and The White Bull) as well as a verse account inspired by Chaucer'S The Wife of Bath's Tale,: What Pleases the Ladies.

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
description: Dorian Gray's portrait painting captures his inner beauty while he has it. Set in finca London, this novel follows the path of painter Basil Hallward as it journeys to the East End and beyond. Blending supernatural elements with aestheticism and Gothic style, these works are fictional.

title: Confessions
description: In 1781, The Confessions was published and its emotional honesty and candid treatment of the author's sexual and intellectual growth shocked Europe. It has since had a more profound impact on European thought. Rousseau created exemplars of reflective living, depicting an isolated individual who was resistant to servitude or habitual behavior but pursued fervent self-centeredness.

title: La Débâcle
description: Zola affirmed that his title signifies not only the end of civilization and the decline of dictatorship, but also the destruction of nations. La Debacle (1892), the penultimate book in the Rougon-Macquart series, depicts the events of the Franco-Prussian War and The Commune of 1870-71. It was the most popular novel of its time among readers, recognized for its meticulous historical research and its emphasis on both war and world peace.

title: Four Gothic Novels
authors: Horace Walpole;William Beckford;Matthew Lewis;Mary W. Shelley
description: The Castle of Otranto (1764) by Horace Walpole was a classic example of Gothic storytelling, known for its macabre and melodramatic themes set in haunted castles or stunning landscapes. It was an instant hit with readers and inspired many of their idols, including William Beckford's Vathek (1786), which features grotesque comedy mixed with exotic beauty in the tale of the ruthless Caliph Vathora'er.

title: The First Philosophers
description: This book provides an exhaustive list of philosophical writings by Presocratics and Sophists, emphasizing the impact of these "first philosophers" on Western thought, including Plato and Aristotle.

title: The Antiquary
description: A young man of noble appearance, who had previously traveled to the north-east of Scotland on a fine summer day in the late 18th century, gave himself boarding in one of the public carriages between Edinburgh and Queen'sferry, prompting Scott to write his personal favourite, which begins with ambiguously wordy scenes that follow naive but fateful boyhood towards the Highlanders.

title: Exemplary Stories
description: Despite being more famous than Don Quixote in their day, Cervantes's Exemplary Stories (1613) stand out for their ability to challenge and delight readers through their mix of picaresque, satirical, and realism.

title: Orestes and Other Plays
description: Euripides explores ethical and political themes in IonOrestes, Phoenician Women, and Suppliant Women plays. He contrasts patriotism and family loyalty with expediency, pragmatism and justice, as well as the idea of "might is right" and clemency.

title: Jane Austen's Letters
description: The letters written by Jane Austen offer a unique perspective on her daily life, much like the novels themselves. They bring to life details such as family and friends, while also providing eloquent descriptions of contemporary life and modern events. We are especially impressed by the author's unapologetic tone in books like Pride and Prejudice and Sense and Sensibility.

title: Agricola and Germany
description: After the assassination of Domitian, Rome's most prominent historian Cornelius Tacitus was inspired to take up his pen and write about it. Agricola is a biography of his late father-in-law and an account of Roman Britain. Germania is dedicated to explaining Rome’s dangers against the Germans, and has had reverberating effects on our understanding of Rome and the northern barbarians.

title: Miss Or Mrs?
description: The melodramatic content is always present and must be catered to.

title: Great Expectations
description: Contains the traditional tale of Pip, Magwitch, Estella, and Miss Havisham.

title: Complete Shorter Fiction
description: The first-ever complete collection of Oscar Wilde's short fiction, including social and literary parodies like "Lord Arthur Savile" and "The Canterville Ghost," well-known fairy tales like the "Happy Prince," "Thunderbeam King," and a fictional portrait called "St. W.H.", and poetry by Wilder as "Pompsons in Proverbs," is now available in one volume.

title: War and Peace
description: Exposes the conventional narrative of the Napoleonic Wars and their aftermath on four Russian families.

title: The Castle of Otranto
description: In 1764, The Castle of Otranto was published anonymously and claimed to be a translation of an Italian chronicle of the crusades. Walpole aimed to combine the two types of romance, as stated in the Preface to the second edition. He includes 'periods of catastrophe, ghostly interventions, revelations about one's identity, and thrilling battles, while simultaneously creating success for invention, entertainment, terror, or pathos.

title: The Bostonians
description: The conflict arises between Olive Chancellor and Basil Ransom, who both want Verena Tarrant to abandon politics for him.

title: The Divine Comedy
authors: Dante Alighieri;Charles Hubert Sisson;David H. Higgins
description: New translation of Dante's epic in blank verse, including a renowned Introduction, diagrams, maps, and notes.

title: Hans Andersen's Fairy Tales
description: This edition features twenty-six fairy tales by Andersen, along with an introduction, a chronology of the author's life and writings, and bibliographical information.

title: The Karamazov Brothers
description: In The Karamazov Brothers (1880), Dostoevsky's final and most exceptional novel, he explores the murder of a determined landowner in Georgia. The sons of the author are involved in this psychological drama, including Ivan, Dmitry, and Alyosha.

title: Daisy Miller and Other Stories
description: The account of Daisy's descent into a corrupt European society was celebrated, as well as Daisy herself, with success; and it has remained one of James' most renowned short stories. Just like the others presented here-- "Pandora," "The Patagonia," and "Four Meetings," it depicts contrasting values in varying cultures. Is the new American girl attractive for her uniqueness or because of her lack of knowledge about social norms?

title: Selected Philosophical Writings
description: St Thomas Aquinas viewed religion as a natural human tendency that led to worship. His ability to recognize the authenticity of this phenomenon and further explore spiritual revelation enabled him to write in contrasting ways. He carefully incorporated varying levels of theology and philosophy into his writings, ranging from an exploration of thought structures to the idea of God as the ultimate creator of all things. This new translation chooses significant parts not only from the Old Testament but also from Latin.

title: The Ladies' Paradise
description: The Ladies' Paradise (Au Bonheur des Dames) chronicles the remarkable growth of the current department store in Paris during the late 1800s. It is a representation of capitalism, the modern city, and the bourgeois family, reflecting the changes that took place in consumer culture and social dynamics at the end of this century. The owner-manager, Octave Mouret, exploits the female customer's desires both personally and professionally.

title: A Sentimental Education
description: As a young provincial with moderate abilities, Frederic Moreau has aspirations of fame, fortune, literature, and art. He is also driven by an immense passion for his hometown of Nogent-sur-Seine. His fascination with the charming Madame Arnoux draws him to Paris and he cultivates her charismatic and outgoing personality in order to be near her.

title: La Dame Aux Camélias
description: The new translation combines the feel for Dumas's style with a lively and informal tone, making this story an irresistible one.

title: First Love and Other Stories
description: The collection includes six of Turgenev's most famous long' short stories, which employ his talents of psychological observation and black comedy to explore diverse themes such as serfdom, love, and revenge on the Russian steppes. All showcase the refined and unmistakable qualities of this writer who is known for his exceptional writing.

title: The Confidence-man
description: Who among the passengers on the Mississippi steamboat Fidele possesses the qualities of a confidence man?

title: The Eclogues ; The Georgics
description: During the period of the 'Second' Triumvirate, a group of poets composed ten short pastoral poems called the Eclogues between 42 and 39 BC. Virgil blended an imagined Arcadia with contemporary history while also using Italian realism to represent real and concealed places and people along with modern events.

title: Scenes of Clerical Life
description: Scenes of Clerical Life, George Eliot's debut novel, was published anonymous in 1857 and was immediately recognized as the creation of a remarkable writer' by the Saturday Review. The three stories that make up the Scene are titled?

title: Jacques the Fatalist and His Master
description: Jacques the Fatalist is not only a tasteful amalgamation of fact and fiction, but also embodies Diderot's philosophy of life.

title: The Notebooks of Leonardo Da Vinci
description: During his lifetime, Leonardo da Vinci carried a collection of notebooks in which he recorded ideas and opinions from personal to professional. He also frequently sketched ideas with explanatory sketches and diagrams. The manuscript that survives contains drafts of letters, whimsical fables, rough treatises, descriptions of water-based art, detailed court records, and jokes among other items.

title: The Admirable Crichton ; Peter Pan ; When Wendy Grew Up ; What Every Woman Knows ; Mary Rose
description: Despite being the most successful playwright in 20 years, J M Barrie's works, particularly his adaptations of Peter Pan and Mary Rose, continue to be highly popular today. He also wrote some of the best children'S plays, including the critically acclaimed Admirable Crichton and What Every Woman Knows, which explore the politics of class and gender, as well as more recent political satire.

title: La chartreuse de Parme
description: Observe the exploits of Fabrizio del Dongo as he becomes a part of Napoleon's army shortly before the Battle of Waterloo, and faces difficulties in keeping his affection for Clelia concealed from the intrigues and secrets of the small court of Parma.

title: Evelina  Or  The History of a Young Lady's Entrance Into the World
description: Frances Burney's debut novel, which has become renowned, is a gripping and provocative portrayal of the glamorous lifestyle in 18th-century London. By handing me my first prize to Lord Orville for being "handsome," she exudes pride and privilege while depicting the fragility of female innocence in an image-obsessed and often cruel society.

title: Aesop's Fables
description: A compilation of common everyday morality tales.

title: A Memoir of Jane Austen
description: This edition features Austen-Leigh's memoir of his aunt Jane Austent, as well as shorter recollections from James Edward' two sisters and two biographical accounts.

title: Presocratic Philosophy: A Very Short Introduction
description: This book delves into the origins of Western philosophy and the first thinkers to formulate ideas about the nature of reality, time, and creation of the universe. It begins with the discovery of a new papyrus fragment from Empedocles' poem and uses its story to highlight how our understanding of early philosophers is shaped by their presentation in later sources. Despite the fact that we have very few works on presocratics, this book offers hints at their intellectual origin.

title: Augustine: A Very Short Introduction
description: The book Very Short Introductions provides accessible and engaging introductions to a diverse array of topics, reflecting the best of modern thought on their core issues. It is both captivating and informative.

title: The Origins of Life
description: -Biologist 01/02/2002's reviewer highly recommends this book as an exciting, thought-provoking, and challenging exploration of various topics.

title: Augustine
description: Explains the manner in which Augustine received his education, addresses the key themes of his writings, and evaluates his impact on Western thought.

title: The Hound of the Baskervilles
description: A man is swept away by an enormous dog in Dartmoor, a wet and wild place in the Southwest of England where it's easy to get lost and fall into the soft earth that can pull him down to his death. The only person left between them is the greatest detective who has ever lived, Sherlock Holmes.

title: Growing Old in America
description: A history of aging in America examines and contrasts actualities and attitudes from the 18th, 19th- and 20th centuries, while proposing practical improvements to the current inadequate system of pensions, social security, medicare, and other entitlements.

title: Alcestis
description: The Alcestis is translated into a vigorous and distinctive style, which highlights the remarkable formal beauty and thematic emphasis of the play.

title: Albion's Seed
description: The initial part of a cultural history of America scrutinizes the diverse lifestyles and traditions of the first waves of immigrants to America and evaluates their significance in modern-day American society.

title: Inferno
description: The translation of the classic Italian epic recounts Dante and Virgil's journey to the nine regions of hell.

title: Paul Revere's Ride
description: Discusses the events that led up to Paul Revere's ride, and emphasizes his significance in the narrative of the Revolutionary War.

title: Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes
description: Introduces Holmes' early years, Civil War encounters, legal profession, and thirty years of service on the U.S. Supreme Court, while also providing new insights into his connection with Clare Castletown.

title: Notebooks of the Mind
description: How do creative people think? Do epic works of art come from words or images? Why do geniuses like Mozart and Einstein seem to appear suddenly, what if not scientific?
